db:article.db:para: This example shows how to use QCustom3DVolume items to display volumetric data.

db:section.db:title: Running the Example
db:section.db:para: To run the example from Qt Creator, open the Welcome mode and select the example from Examples. For more information, visit Building and Running an Example.

For the texture data we use the data we created earlier based on some height maps. db:section.db:title: Slicing into the Volume
db:section.db:para: Unless the volume is largely transparent, you can only see the surface of it, which is often not very helpful. db:section.db:title: Adjusting Volume Transparency
db:section.db:para: Sometimes viewing just the slices doesn't give you a good understanding of the volume's internal structure. QCustom3DVolume provides two properties that can be used to adjust the volume transparency:

The QCustom3DVolume::alphaMultiplier is a general multiplier that is applied to the alpha value of each voxel of the volume. It makes it possible to add uniform transparency to the already somewhat transparent portions of the volume to reveal internal opaque details. This multiplier doesn't affect colors that are fully opaque, unless the QCustom3DVolume::preserveOpacity property is set to false.

An alternative way to adjust the transparency of the volume is adjust the alpha values of the voxels directly. For eight bit indexed textures, this is done simply by modifying and resetting the color table:

db:section.db:title: High Definition vs. Low Definition Shader
db:section.db:para: By default the volume rendering uses the high definition shader. It accounts for each voxel of the volume with correct weight when ray-tracing the volume contents, providing an accurate representation of even the finer details of the volume. However, this is computationally very expensive, so the frame rate suffers. If rendering speed is more important than pixel-perfect accuracy of the volume contents, you can take the much faster low definition shader into use by setting false for QCustom3DVolume::useHighDefShader property. The low definition shader achieves the speed by making compromises on the accuracy, so it doesn't guarantee each voxel of the volume will be sampled. This can lead to flickering and/or other rendering artifacts on the finer details of the volume.
